Sentence: With a T c substantially higher than NbTi, superconducting materials such as Nb 3 Sn (T c ï =ï 17 K) , MgB 2 (T c ï =ï 39 K) , YBCO (T c ï =ï 93 K) , BSCCO (T c ï =ï 108 K) , and Bi- (T c ï =ï 90-95 K) are all potential candidates for conduction cooled magnet designs.
Since the majority of today's clinical MRI systems use 1.5 and 3 T magnets, the feasibility of MRI magnets at these field strengths using MgB 2 superconducting wire should be explored.

With a T c substantially higher than NbTi, superconducting materials such as Nb 3 Sn (T c ï =ï 17 K) , MgB 2 (T c ï =ï 39 K) , YBCO (T c ï =ï 93 K) , BSCCO (T c ï =ï 108 K) , and Bi- (T c ï =ï 90-95 K) are all potential candidates for conduction cooled magnet designs.
With a critical temperature of 39 K, MgB 2 super- conducting wire can facilitate conduction cooled 1.5 T or 3.0 T magnets that eliminate the need for LHe.
The superconductor is operated below both the transition temperature of MgB 2 of 39 K and the critical current value at the desired magnetic field and temperature so that no power loss occurs.

To maximize the current capacity of the NbTi wires (i.e. critical current), and to enable operation in persistent current mode, the superconducting magnets are cooled to temperatures well below the critical temperature 9 K. Typically, NbTi based MRI magnets are operated at temperature of 4.2 K by completely submersing the magnet coils in a LHe bath.
